channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12956] Binding to 0.0.0.0 is broken after HBASE-10569
item.description: After the Region Server and Master code was merged, we lost the functionality to bind to 0.0.0.0 via hbase.regionserver.ipc.address and znodes now get created with the wildcard address which means that RSs and the master cannot connect to each other. Thanks to Dima Spivak for reporting the issue.
item.summary: Binding to 0.0.0.0 is broken after HBASE-10569

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This looks important. What happens when hbase.regionserver.ipc.address is set to 0.0.0.0? We put 0.0.0.0 to zk as the master address?
Thats correct Enis Soztutar, also RS znodes report as 0.0.0.0 I'm testing a patch as I type this.
Yep, you end up with 0.0.0.0 znodes.

I'm testing a patch as I type this.

Any update on the patch?

Ok, I'm gonna sink the release candidate because this is an important regression to fix. I've reproduced this with a cluster hbase.regionserver.ipc.address=0.0.0.0.


hbase(main):001:0> zk_dump

HBase is rooted at /hbase

Active master address: 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174431955

Backup master addresses:

Region server holding hbase:meta: os-enis-hbase-1.0-test-feb5-1.novalocal,16020,1423173791765

Region servers:

 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174437687

 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174436415

 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174434835

 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174433653

 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0,16020,1423174438855

Enis Soztutar got pulled into some requests and I haven't had the chance to upload the patch rebased to include the changes form Ted Yu in HBASE-12954. Let me upload a patch this afternoon so we can get a new RC today or tomorrow.
HBASE-12954 will not make into 1.0. If you have a patch without those changes, I can test it out for branch-1.0.
Thats fine Enis Soztutar how ever without HBASE-12954 you cannot bind to an IP different to 0.0.0.0 or the default host IP address (e.g. no way to use 127.0.0.1 in hbase.regionserver.ipc.address)

Thats fine Enis Soztutar how ever without HBASE-12954 you cannot bind to an IP different to 0.0.0.0 or the default host IP address (e.g. no way to use 127.0.0.1 in hbase.regionserver.ipc.address)

Not sure I understand it. Users might want to do the same setup as in 0.98 and 0.94, no? HBASE-12954 is not needed for a setup where the RS is multi homed, bind address is 0.0.0.0, but hostnames are resolved via reverse DNS.

Probably I didn't explain this correctly, currently hbase.regionserver.ipc.address can accept any valid IP from the active interfaces from the RS host. Even is possible to bind to 0.0.0.0 after the patch, it won't be possible to bind to other IP addresses different to the default IP and 0.0.0.0. Maybe its a very edgy case that we can tackle after HBASE-12954.

The patch mimics what we do in HMaster for 0.98, which is the correct approach.
Esteban Gutierrez, RpcServer.java does not use isa at all after this patch. Maybe we can just pass either the bindAddress or the isa from RSRpcServices. Otherwise +1.
Nice test. Let me try this in a cluster.
I've tested the patch at my cluster. Both hbase.regionserver.ipc.address works as before. zk dumps does not show anything unusual.
Hey Enis Soztutar I removed isa as suggested, please let me know if that is what you were thinking.

I was thinking that we do not need both bindAddress, and isa in RpcServer.
The following line is equal to just using bindAddress:


isa.equals(bindAddress) ? isa : bindAddress

What I had in mind is your exact same patch, but without the RpcServer changes, and instead of 


     rpcServer = new RpcServer(rs, name, getServices(),

-      initialIsa, // BindAddress is IP we got for this server.

+      initialIsa,

+      bindAddress, // BindAddress is IP we got for this server.

just 


     rpcServer = new RpcServer(rs, name, getServices(),

-      initialIsa, // BindAddress is IP we got for this server.

+      bindAddress, // BindAddress is IP we got for this server.

let me know if this makes sense.
